rina Guseva Canua,∗, Thomas F. Batesonb, Veronique Bouvardc, Maximilien Debiad, hantal Diond,e, Kai Savolainenf, Il-Je Yug

a b s t r a c t
In an emerging field of nanotechnologies, assessment of exposure to carbon nanotubes (CNT) and carbon nanofibers (CNF) is an integral component of occupational and environmental epidemiology, risk assessment and management, as well as regulatory actions. The current state of knowledge on exposure to carbon-based fibrous nanomaterials among workers, consumers and general population was studied in frame of the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) Monographs-Volume 111 “Some Nanomaterials and Some Fibres”. Completeness and reliability of available exposure data for use in epidemiology and risk assessment were assessed. Occupational exposure to CNT/CNF may be of concern at all stages of the material life-cycle from research through manufacture to use and disposal. Consumer and environmental exposures are only estimated by modeled data. The available information of the final
xposure metric steps of the life-cycle of these materials remains incomplete so far regarding amounts of handled materials and levels of exposure. The quality and amount of information available on the uses and applications of CNT/CNF should be improved to enable quantitative assessment of human exposure to these materials. For that, coordinated effort in producing surveys and exposure inventories based on harmonized strategy of material test, exposure measurement and reporting results is strongly encouraged.

. Introduction
In 2014, an advisory Group of experts meeting every 5 ears to recommend priorities for the International Agency for esearch on Cancer (IARC), listed carbon-based nanomaterials [i.e. ingle-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNT), multi-walled carbon anotubes (MWCNT), and carbon nanofibers (CNF)] as high priorty agents to be evaluated for by the IARC Monographs Program. n October 2014, the IARC Monograph Volume 111 Working Group lassified the well-characterized CNT sample Mitsui MWCNT-7 as possibly carcinogenic to humans” (Group 2B) based on sufficient vidence in animal bioassays. CNT other than Mitsui MWCNT-7 ere classified in Group 3 (“not classifiable as to their carcinoenicity to humans”) based on limited evidence in animal bioassays or MWCNT with physical dimensions similar to MWCNT-7, and nadequate evidence for SWCNT (Grosse et al., 2014). A Group 3 lassification is not a determination of non-carcinogenicity or overll safety. It means that further research is needed, especially when xposures are widespread. It was the case for the CNT whose evalation was done on the available published literature in which pidemiological studies are completely lacking. The recent producion and/or use of the CNT and the latency time period potentially ecessary between exposure to CNT and cancer development may ot have been reached yet.
This review presents the current state of knowledge on exposure o carbon-based fibrous nanomaterials among workers, consumers nd general population. More specifically, it aims at describing the xposed work population, the extent of the exposure in different arget-populations, and the life-cycle steps of CNT/CNF-containing roducts of greatest exposure potential. The final goal is to address he quality of available exposure data in terms of completeness, recision and reliability for use in epidemiological and risk assessent studies as well as necessary improvements to fill the key data aps.
. Material and methods
.1. Exposure agent
Depending on the process, the shape and physical and chemical haracteristics (e.g. diameter, length) of the carbon based fibrous anomaterial vary (Fig. 1). Because CNF may be produced as impuities during the CNT synthesis, both are often discussed together, s an issue of nomenclature.
.2. Literature search and extracted information
PubMed and Scopus databases were searched for period 000–2014 to identify studies dealing with exposure to CNT/CNF, xcluding studies on medical application. References were earched using all combinations of keywords based on the followng structure: “assessment” & “exposure” & “carbon nanotube”. he word “assessment” was alternatively replaced by “meaurement”, “estimation”, and “modelling”. The word “exposure”
as alternatively replaced by “release” and by qualitative adjecives describing the exposure, namely “human”, “occupational”, environmental”, “consumer”, and “life-cycle”. The word “carbon anotube” was alternatively replaced by the alternative names of
. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 174
the carbonaceous nanofibers of interest, namely “single-walled carbon nanotube”, “double-walled carbon nanotube”, “multi-walled carbon nanotube”, “carbon nanofibers” and their abbreviations. References in papers were reviewed for additional sources. Relevant articles published in English in peer-reviewed journals were retained and classified by exposure origin, target population, and study approach (Fig. 2). The quality of the exposure measurement protocol and results reporting were reviewed, with a focus on the following parameters: exposure/release potential, exposure/release extent (amount) and unit of measurement, presence of CNT/CNF (specificity) and morphology of the released material.
3. Results and discussion
3.1. Exposure origin, pathway, and target populations during CNT/CNF life cycle
3.1.1. Occupational exposure • Research and development (R&D): academic and private labora-
tory workers are involved in the material conception, engineering and characterization. Laboratory workers usually work under experimental conditions with novel materials, instruments, and methods, so they may represent a distinct population with respect to potential occupational exposure. • Primary manufacturers: workers at facilities producing CNT/CNF sold to researchers or industry. • Secondary manufactures: workers at facilities purchasing CNT/CNF for the production of advanced materials (composite, thermoplastic materials) or for use in flexible panel circuits, lighting and other applications.
Many facilities are hybrid producer/professional users. They produce CNT/CNF and subsequently incorporate them into a product. Most facilities also perform developmental work on their own materials and products. For these reasons, R&D workers from primary and secondary manufacturers are considered together.
For workers involved in the manufacturing stage of CNT/CNF, the principal pathway for exposure is by inhalation of powder, or aerosolized CNT/CNF during production, formulation and packaging of product, and professional use of the CNT/CNF-enabling product (Table 1). Dermal exposure to spills or dusts from the production during the formulation process by secondary manufacturers is another likely pathway for occupational exposure.
3.1.2. Consumer exposure Consumers might be exposed during normal use of CNT/CNFcontaining products when mechanical, thermal, and biochemical interactions lead to product degradation. Environmental conditions of CNT/CNF composites uses influence the release potential; weathering is affected by moisture, salinity, pressure, temperature and light radiation, and will vary in marine or fresh water environments, or with altitude and biogeochemical conditions of exposure (Nowack et al., 2013). For example, CNT/polymer composite building will be subject to weathering stresses, and less to mechanical stresses. In contrast, a CNT/polymer composite used in laptop computer housing will be subject to mechanical stress (e.g. by scratching or cracking). In this case, the likelihood of release of free CNT/CNF is small because of the high-energy input needed. During

During professional use of the CNT/CNF-containing comosite products activities with high-energy input such as cutting, rinding, shredding, sanding, drilling, machining, and weathering re common scenarios for the release of inhalable CNT/CNF conaining material (Froggett et al., 2014).
.1.3. Environmental exposure The main pathways of environmental release of CNT/CNF strucures and subsequent human exposure are: (1) release into surface nd air, via release of free particles added within the manufacturing rocesses into the manufacturing plant waste streams; (2) intenional or unintentional releases during use of products; (3) during isposal or recycling of the product (Ging et al., 2014).
Waste disposal including landfilling, recycling or incineration ould result in environmental release of CNT/CNF structures and ubsequent human exposure. The releases are more likely to occur rom environmental rather than human influences, such as weathring effects after waste treatment. Landfilled composite could lowly break down and potentially release CNT/CNF structures to he leachate. If the landfill is not well controlled, release could be via
-based fibrous nanomaterials at different steps of their life-cycle.
dust from weathered composites. Recycling could release CNT/CNF structures to the atmosphere during processing, or to a new material with an alternative use. Incineration could release CNT/CNF from a composite; whether they are released to the atmosphere, or become part of fly ash or bottom ash if the incineration conditions do not degrade the CNT/CNF into carbon dioxide (CO2), normally at a burning temperature above 1000 ◦C under oxygen. If the composite product was used in an application that involved washing with water, release into wastewater is possible resulting in either a land or aquatic pathway (Gottschalk et al., 2009). For workers at waste treatment and recycling facilities, potential occupational exposure is noteworthy, particularly if there are release of CNT/CNF structures (shredding, abrasion) and poor occupational hygiene practices for waste and by-products disposal (Nowack et al., 2013).
3.2. Exposure during engineering, primary and secondary manufacturing
Currently available occupational-exposure data are limited, because production and use of CNT/CNF materials are relatively recent and workforce sizes remain small. Some sources stated that general production of CNT was estimated to surpass the
I. Guseva Canu et al. / International Journal of Hygiene and Environmental Health 219 (2016) 166–175 169
k t m a h u i iloton level and is expected to more than double in the next hree years (Kingston et al., 2014), while others reported an estiated annual global production volume of 250 tons/year for CNT nd >500 tons/year for CNF (Holden et al., 2014). Available data are eterogeneous due to high variability of methods and instruments sed for exposure sampling and analysis and of criteria used for nterpreting their results.
For documenting occupational exposure two types of studies were used: experimental exposure-simulation studies and field (or onsite) studies, conducted in real occupational settings (Fig. 2).
Experimental studies aim at understanding the mechanism of the release of CNT/CNF structures in the well-controlled laboratory conditions, and at qualifying the released material (i.e. morphology, physicochemical characteristics). Most experimental studies

During the chemical vapor deposition (CVD) SWCNT synthesis nd MWCNT growth Tsai et al. (2009) measured particle number oncentration in personal-breathing zones (PBZ) and air samles (Table S1). PBZ samples had particle concentrations similar o background particle concentrations. Transmission electronic
icroscopy (TEM) analysis of MWCNT samples indicated the resence of individual particles as small as 20 nm with particle gglomerates as large as 300 nm. Few individual MWCNT were bserved; MWCNT were often accompanied by clusters of carbon nd iron particles. Tubes diameters were about 50 nm.
Bello et al. (2008) reported no increase in total airborne partile concentrations (compared with background) neither during the emoval of MWCNT from the reactor furnace nor during detachent of MWCNT from the growth substrate (with a razor blade), nd no detectable quantity of MWCNT neither as individual tubes or as agglomerates in personal PBZ samples.
Johnson et al. (2010) reported significantly greater particle conentrations during the sonication of MWCNT water samples, than hose found during the weighing and transferring of dry MWCTs. TEM analysis revealed MWCNT agglomerates 500–1000 nm n diameter. In summary, these experimental studies assessed exposure as article number of CNT, mainly MWCNT. Two of three reported the elease of MWCNT agglomerates, free or embedded in clusters of arbon and other particles. No release of any SWCNT was reported. o experimental studies for CNF releases were found.
Twenty-one onsite studies conducted in R&D laboratories, mall-scale pilot-production facilities, and, more rarely, large-scale rimary or secondary manufacturer/user facilities were reviewed. hese studies have been conducted in the USA (eleven), the epublic of Korea (four), Japan (four), and Europe (two), one n Sweden and one in The Netherlands. Nineteen of the studes reported exposure results in terms of mass concentration r particle number. These results are summarized in detail in able S1. Table S2 summarizes the highest levels reported in these tudies.
In the USA, Maynard et al. (2004) collected the total mass of a etal catalyst used to produce SWCNT and then estimated expoures to SWCNT at 0.7–53 g/m3. Area samples, as analyzed using canning electronic microscopy (SEM), showed relatively few paricles of 100 m to 1 mm in diameter, with very few nanotubes. o evidence of millimeter-sized nanotube material clumps was ound in aerosol samples from laser-ablated material. No increase n the number of fine particles was found, suggesting that released articles tend to be larger than 1 m in diameter.
Within the laboratory CNF processing area, Methner et al. (2007) ound air concentrations of 2–64 times those in a nearby office area. ominant particle sizes appeared to be in the 30–200 nm range particles of outdoor origin). Particles having a diameter of about 00 nm or greater were found in greater number during wet-saw utting, while the number of particles having a diameter of about 00 nm or greater were elevated during the weighing and mixng of CNF. TEM revealed some fibers with diameters larger than 00 nm (criterion used to define a nanofibre). The majority of fibers ppeared as loosely bundled agglomerates rather than as single bers.
In a commercial nanotechnology facility producing NT by arc reaction, Yeganeh et al. (2008) reported 0,000–50,000 particles/cm3 (in the range 14–673 nm) in the ork area during periods of arc reaction. Measured PM2.5 mass oncentrations ranged from 50 to 125 g/m3.

In a field survey of twelve facilities handling carbonaceous nanomaterials, Methner et al. (2010) reported that inhalable mass of total carbon concentration (TC) in PBZ samples ranged between 64 and 1094 g/m3, while that from source-specific air samples ranged between 12 and 1839 g/m3. The highest CNF concentration was measured in samples collected during drying and manual scooping of the processed CNF (1839 and 1729 g/m3, respectively). Most of the collected samples showed evidence of CNT/CNF structures by TEM.
A task-based comparative assessment by Methner et al. (2012b) found that surface grinding of composite material and manually transferring dry CNF produced substantial increases in particle-number (range = 20,000–490,000 particles/cm3). Concomitant increases in mass concentration were also associated with most tasks. Nearly 90% of all samples examined via TEM indicated that releases of CNF do occur. PBZ samples ranged from non-detectable to 1000 g/m3, with 90% of the samples having detectable amounts of elemental carbon (EC). The highest measured PBZ sample occurred during wet-saw cutting of composite without controls. The majority of samples contained mostly nonagglomerated CNF, whereas a smaller subset of samples contained a larger amount of loosely agglomerated CNF.
A more recent study (Methner et al., 2012a) found few detectable exposures during short duration tasks at four SWCNT or CNF downstream-user facilities. Although few of the PBZ samples had measurable EC concentrations, most of the collected samples showed evidence of SWCNT or CNF exposure by SEM.
In eight-hour work shift PBZ samples (Birch et al., 2011) found respirable EC concentration higher than in the corresponding area air samples. TEM analysis showed that most of the particles collected in the thermal treatment were bundled/entangled structures. Most fibrous particles had aerodynamic diameters <0.25 m. Birch et al. concluded that respirable mass estimated by photometer was the most useful on-site indicator of CNFs while total particle number (9.0 × 104 to 1.15 × 106 per cm3) and active surface area (430–1440 m2/cm3) measurements, determined using direct-reading instruments (DRI), were not useful indicators of CNF exposure.
Dahm et al. (2012) visited six primary and secondary manufacturer sites. The highest CNT/CNF structure counts from the primary manufacturers came from harvesting operations that did not employ engineering control measures. The two highest structure counts at secondary manufactures were detected during manual transferring of CNF (1.613 and 0.295 structures/cm3). An agreement between the PBZ and area sample collected for the mass concentration of EC and the side-by-side samples collected for TEM analysis was evaluated with a Pearson correlation coefficient of 0.44 (p = 0.01). No clear pattern emerged linking particle number, respirable mass, and active surface-area measurements determined using DRI for EC or TEM data (CNT/CNF-structure counts) (Dahm et al., 2013).
The most recent study (Dahm et al., 2015) collected inhalable PBZ samples at nine CNT/CNF manufacturers and users sites and both inhalable and respirable PBZ at five other sites for comparison with the recommended exposure limit (REL) for CNT (1 g/m3 of EC for the respirable size fraction; NIOSH, 2013). Overall, EC PBZ and area samples were below the REL. PBZ samples analyzed by TEM showed concentrations ranging from 0.0001 to 1.613 CNT/CNFstructures/cm3 (geometric mean = 0.008, 8-hour time weighted average (8 h-TWA) = 0.003 structures/cm3). The most common CNT structure sizes were found to be larger agglomerates in the 2–5 m range as well as agglomerates >5 m. A statistically significant correlation was observed between inhalable samples for EC mass and structure counts by TEM (Spearman = 0.39, p < 0.0001).

WCNT-structures were found only in facilities with no expoure controls (0.003 tubes/cm3). MWCNT tube structures were urrounded by small particles which were mainly iron.
In two printing electronics workplaces using CNT and nanoilver conductive ink or nano-film, Lee et al. (2013) monitored mass oncentrations of total suspended particulates in PBZ samples. he 8 h-TWA ranged 0.00068–0.0091 mg/m3, with no indication of xposure to CNT.
At a workplace manufacturing MWCNT (Lee et al., 2014) easured workers’ inhalable EC concentration of 6.2–9.3 g/m3. EM analyses showed agglomerated MWCNT with mostly caron content. Estimated respirable mass concentrations ranged .6–2.3 g/m3.
In Japan, Ogura et al. (2011) investigated the release potential f super-growth SWCNT. Synthesized by the water-assisted CVD ethod, these CNT have an outer diameter of 3 nm and length up o 2.5 mm and 99.98% purity. Airborne CNT were only found inside he enclosures except for a small amount of CNT released from the nclosure during opening.
At a pilot-scale plant where SWCNT were synthesized, harested, and packed, Ogura et al. (2013a) observed no CNTs outside f enclosure whereas inside of enclosure micron-sized CNT clusters ere found.
At a factory that produces conductive fabric using MWCNT oated yarn Takaya et al. (2012) conducted carbon analysis accordng to the protocol outlined by Ono-Ogasawara and Myojo (2011)
here EC was oxidized at 920 ◦C (defined as EC3 sub-fraction) and as considered to be an index for MWCNT-containing particle elease. The measured mass concentration of EC3 in PBZ samles during the weaving was 0.035 mg/m3 in the morning and .0048 mg/m3 in the afternoon. No nanosize individual fibrous WCNT-particles were observed on SEM but many submicron-size articles that seemed to be fragments of yarn. These particles were roduced by mechanical forces of weaving. The nanosize fibers n the surface of the micron-size fragments were considered as WCNT. Ono-Ogasawara et al. Bekker et al. (2015) collected real time particle-concentration, particle-size distribution, filter-based samples at five academic research laboratories. The CNT exposure was declared “possible/not excluded” during weighing CNT powder and during manual harvesting CNT grown on stainless steel. In both settings, CNT clusters of 0.5–10 m were found in PBZ and near-field samples, with no free CNT. No precision on CNT type was provided.
In summary, the available onsite studies provide strong evidence that exposure of workers to CNT/CNF material may occur, especially at workstations where no exposure-control measurement are implemented. In almost situations where detectable amounts of either EC or EC3 sub-fraction were found, the presence of CNT/CNF material was confirmed by TEM/SEM analyses of PBZ or area air samples. More often, CNT were found to be attached to the soot or metal catalyzed particles, or embedded to other impurities, or in form of large entangled agglomerates.
Only four studies attempted to quantify CNT/CNF concentrations in PBZ samples because CNT/CNF were only rarely observed in SEM and TEM analyses and no validated protocol is available for counting such different structures. Nevertheless, different counting criteria were applied precluding various statistical treatments of the results. The reported values range between 0.003 and 0.30 structures/cm3 (s/cm3) for CNF, 0.003 and 0.01 s/cm3 for SWCNT and 0.008 and 193.6 s/cm3 for MWCNT, with the worst situation described in R&D laboratories as compared to industrial settings (Table S2). The operations yielding the highest release of CNT/CNF material/cm3 include blending, transferring, sieving, pouring and weighing as well as CNTs production in both, CVD and arc discharge processes, which encompasses synthesis, harvesting from the reactor and subsequent reactor clean-out.
When EC concentration is considered, values as high as 7–1000 g/m3, 7.4–10 g/m3, and 0.68–38 g/m3 were measured in PBZ samples for workers handling CNF, MWCNT and SWCNT, respectively (Table S2). Operations with the highest EC concentrations include wet-saw cutting of CNF, harvesting of CNT from the reactor, transferring CNTs and loading flasks with CNTs, use of batch mixer, as well as CNTs production and cleaving of deposits. Only six studies (41%) had measurable EC concentration. Results are difficult to compare because differing protocols that were applied (e.g. large variations in oxidation temperatures used, oxidation time at each step, different strategies to correct for positive or negative artifacts from organic carbon, etc.) Consequently the reported values should be interpreted cautiously. Only three studies (Birch et al., 2011; Dahm et al., 2015; Hedmer et al., 2014) employed the recommended sampling and analytical method for comparing CNT concentration with the REL (NIOSH, 2013). Additionally, one Korean study (Lee et al., 2014) and two Japanese studies (Ogura et al., 2013a; Ono-Ogasawara et al., 2015) provided estimated and measured respirable EC concentrations, respectively. In many cases reported values were above the NIOSH REL for CNT.
3.3. Exposure during using and repairing
Use and inclusion of CNT into consumer-goods (e.g. sporting goods, packaging, and textiles) are increasing. Many other applications are nearing commercial readiness, including structuralaerospace composites, flame-retardant composites, gas sensors, spun CNT-fiber textiles, semiconductor interconnects, nano-electromechanical systems, transparent electrodes, supercapacitors, photovoltaic devices, thermal-management systems, sorbents, skincare products, and antibacterial packaging (Kingston et al., 2014).
Data regarding the release of CNT/CNF during use and repairs of CNT/CNF-containing consumer products in real conditions do not exist yet (Bekker et al., 2013; Honnert and Grzebyk, 2014). To cover

Softer, more flexible polymer matrices such as polyethylene and polyurethane exhibit stronger resistance to release of CNT due to mechanical degradation, while harder resins such epoxies have a higher potential for release. The potential for release of MWCNT from selected types of CNT-polymer composites is low in typical consumer applications unless the nanocomposite is exposed to conditions degrading the bulk integrity of the polymer matrix.
In summary, the limited number of studies on SWCNT and CNF-composites precludes drawing conclusions. For MWCNTcomposites, the expected release scenarios may include free standing CNT, although agglomerated CNT, and composite fragments with- and without protruding CNT are most commonly released entities. Depending on the applied shear force during the abrasion process, released MWCNT will be shorter than the processed CNT in the composite (Schlagenhauf et al., 2014). Weathering studies showed that CNT formed a network attached to the samples, but most studies investigated the worst case, where the composite was not protected by additives. During the fire-release studies a network of CNT/CNF was formed in the char suggesting that CNT/CNF can be released from the char into the air. Overall, release of free CNT during normal use of consumer products seems unlikely. However, exposure to CNT embedded in or attached to small polymer fragments, cannot be excluded and should be assessed quantitatively.
Although consumer exposure is likely to be negligible, occupational exposure during professional use of CNT/CNF-polymer composites should be considered more thoroughly. Professional use involves high-energy input transformations of the composite, corresponding to scenarios with higher release rates, as compared with consumer use of composites products. Experimental studies do not allow for comparison with REL (NIOSH, 2013), expressed in mass concentration units, because releases are often described in term of particle-number concentration by particle size. For this reason these studies are indicative of potential exposure but less relevant for quantitative exposure-assessment than onsite exposure assessment studies performed under real exposure conditions.
3.4. Exposure from waste disposal and environment
Studies on nanomaterial release and resulting environmental concentrations may be split into three main categories: (1) experimental studies designed to measure application-specific CNT/CNF-release which provide the most concrete basis describing and estimating emission scenarios, (2) analytical studies of CNT/CNF concentration in environmental compartments, and (3) studies focused on the development of models that account for the entire life cycle release of CNT/CNF from various applications (Fig. 2). This life-cycle approach combines potential applications and release scenarios to determine the levels of particular nanomaterials entering the environment and for predicting initial environmental concentrations.
No experimental studies for end-of-life scenarios of CNTpolymer products were available. For CNF, only two studies investigated the release potential for conditions simulating waste incineration (Nyden and Uddin, 2011; Uddin and Nyden, 2011). After thermal degradation at control oxygen and temperatures above 1000 ◦C, the fire smoke from CNF-polyurethanes was soot with no remaining fibers.
No analytical studies reporting measured environmental concentrations for CNT/CNF have been published yet, probably due to lack of appropriate methods for detecting, characterizing and quantifying CNT/CNF in complex natural media (Gottschalk et al.,

.5. Summary of CNT/CNF exposure information available for risk ssessment
As shown in Table 1, occupational exposure to CNT/CNF and NT/CNF-containing particles is of greatest concern, through the
ife-cycle. Release of CNT/CNF structures can occur during expermental processes or processes under development in research acilities, during incidental or accidental events, and during open roduction process. Situations with a closed production line,
and Environmental Health 219 (2016) 166–175 173
generally result in adequate containment of the processes; releases of CNT/CNF structures and exposure may only occur after opening the reactor, for collecting test samples or in case of a leak or spill. Fracturing, abrasion of nano-enabled products and other so-called end-of life activities (recycling and waste-treatment processes) also present potential risks for workers. Alternatively, consumer and general population exposures from environmental release of CNT/CNF are very small.
Onsite (real-life) exposure-measurement studies only cover early life-cycle stages, and limited set of tasks and occupational settings. Use stage was almost entirely characterized by experimental studies and end-of-life activities by modeling studies. These studies focused on the release of CNT/CNF and resulting environmental exposure rather than individual occupational exposure (Table 1).
Existing data are insufficient to quantify the amounts of CNT/CNF produced, used, consumed, or to quantify the resulting exposure. The lack of validated best practices precludes harmonization in measurement strategies, analysis, and reporting of measurement data. This hampers exposure and risk assessments. Mass-based approaches are a good starting point to evaluate nanotechnology risk, but there are other parameters that become more relevant in the case of CNT/CNF; for example, concentration of fibers or CNT/CNF-structures.
There is still no consensus on exposure metrics that would best correlate with adverse health outcomes. During the first studies, gravimetric concentration was measured for total suspended particles, then for the respirable or alveolar fraction of the aerosol or for particles smaller than 2.5 m (Tables S1 and S2). With development of the real-time aerosol monitoring instruments, particle-concentration and specific or active surface-area measurements results became available. However, such results were often reported without harmonized strategy, for only certain ranges of particle size, depending on the instruments availability and their specifications. Compared to the gravimetric concentration, which has problems for particles in the ultrafine size range (<0.1 m), particle-number concentration is often dominated by ultrafine or non-engineered nanoparticle sources and thus unspecific for CNT/CNFs, which occur mainly as micrometer-sized aggregates (Dahm et al., 2013). To search a more specific metric of CNT/CNF concentration, methods to measure the chemical specific mass concentration of total and EC were used. This includes the NIOSH 5040 method (NIOSH, 2006) for establishing the REL for CNT/CNF (NIOSH, 2013) and its variations (Hedmer et al., 2014; Ono-Ogasawara et al., 2015; Takaya et al., 2012). In parallel, methods for counting fibrous material using electron microscopy have been evolved (Chen et al., 2012; Hedmer et al., 2014). Although counting of CNT/CNF-containing structures could be a sufficiently selective and sensitive method for future quantification of CNT/CNF exposure, available data still cannot be summarized for mean values and min-max value range because of important variations in counting protocols. An additional difficulty arises from the diversity of the CNT/CNF material, because its physical and chemical properties influence their potential release, spread, and state causing the standardization of the count protocol to be even more difficult, particularly in a context of rapidly changing manufacture technology to fulfill customers’ requests. Transformations of CNT/CNF-containing products by mechanical and environmental stresses during lifecycle also increase the material variability.
A careful reading of the current available literature suggests that exposure and release of MWCNT were studied more extensively than that of SWCNT and CNF. While the SWCNT are less common in polymer-composite material compared to MWCNT, the CNF market was estimated to be double the CNT market (Holden et al., 2014). This calls for redefinition of the research objectives, in order to prioritize the risk assessment for the most common materials.

.6. Further perspectives
There is a need for realistic release scenarios to harmonize esearch on nanotoxicology, occupational health and safety, and xposure assessments. Some tools have been developed to predict he exposure; the outcomes however, are informed speculations, ecause of a lack of validation against measurement data in the eld. This calls for more targeted actions to prioritize research imed at completion of the dataset required for risk assessment f CNT/CNF. This would involve running standard tests for careully selected groups of materials, representing key occupational, onsumer and ecological applications. Long term chronic anial bioassays simulating as closely as possible natural conditions ith respect to aging and altering CNT/CNF-enabling products are equired. Additionally, important information is lacking to allow informed isk assessment of CNT/CNF: (1) reports on amounts of nanomateial production and of nanomaterial containing-products sold in a articular region; (2) inventory of nanomaterial products indicatng their concentrations and specific properties (size distribution, ossible functionalization, shape etc.); (3) experimental/analytical ata on the main emission sources, pathways, amounts and orms.
In the context of ongoing globalization, there is a risk that roduction of potentially hazardous carbonaceous engineered anomaterials by the industry be moved from developed to develping countries where occupational hygiene and safety regulations n workplace may be weaker. Industry has to disclose more etailed information; for example, quantities used, allocation of anomaterials for different purposes, surface/volume applications, article size, and functionalization, at least for a scientific-based isk assessment. Regulators have to encourage dissemination of his information in an efficient way. International actions on har-
onization of exposure measurement and reporting methods nd material testing coordinated by OECD, WHO and assimiated institutions should contribute to improvement of the current ituation.
. Conclusion
Exposure to CNT/CNF may be of concern at all stages of the ife-cycle from research through manufacture and production o use and end-of-life. Occupational exposure to CNT/CNF and NT/CNF-containing particles is of greatest concern, through the ife-cycle. Alternatively, consumer and general population expoures from environmental release of CNT/CNF are very small. owever, consumer and environmental exposures are only estiated by modeled data. Onsite (real-life) exposure-measurement tudies only cover early life-cycle stages, and limited set of tasks nd occupational settings. Available information of the final steps f the life-cycle progresses currently remains incomplete regarding he amounts of handled materials and levels of exposure. Morever, exposure and release of MWCNT are studied more extensively han that of SWCNT and CNF. While the SWCNT are less com-
on in polymer-composite material compared to MWCNT, the CNF arket was estimated to be double the CNT market. This calls for edefinition of the research objectives, in order to prioritize the isk assessment for the most common materials. The quality and mount of information available on the uses and applications of NT/CNF should be improved to enable quantitative assessment of uman exposure to these materials. For that, coordinated effort in roducing surveys and exposure inventories based on harmonized trategy of material test, exposure measurement and reporting esults is strongly encouraged.

referenceMentions.context: Environmental conditions of CNT/CNF composites uses influence the release potential; weathering is affected by moisture, salinity, pressure, temperature and light radiation, and will vary in marine or fresh water environments, or with altitude and biogeochemical conditions of exposure (Nowack et al., 2013).

During professional use of the CNT/CNF-containing comosite products activities with high-energy input such as cutting, rinding, shredding, sanding, drilling, machining, and weathering re common scenarios for the release of inhalable CNT/CNF conaining material (Froggett et al., 2014).

Environmental exposure The main pathways of environmental release of CNT/CNF strucures and subsequent human exposure are: (1) release into surface nd air, via release of free particles added within the manufacturing rocesses into the manufacturing plant waste streams; (2) intenional or unintentional releases during use of products; (3) during isposal or recycling of the product (Ging et al., 2014).

For workers at waste treatment and recycling facilities, potential occupational exposure is noteworthy, particularly if there are release of CNT/CNF structures (shredding, abrasion) and poor occupational hygiene practices for waste and by-products disposal (Nowack et al., 2013).

The most recent study (Dahm et al., 2015) collected inhalable PBZ samples at nine CNT/CNF manufacturers and users sites and both inhalable and respirable PBZ at five other sites for comparison with the recommended exposure limit (REL) for CNT (1 g/m3 of EC for the respirable size fraction; NIOSH, 2013).

In a field survey of twelve facilities handling carbonaceous nanomaterials, Methner et al. (2010) reported that inhalable mass of total carbon concentration (TC) in PBZ samples ranged between 64 and 1094 g/m3, while that from source-specific air samples ranged between 12 and 1839 g/m3.

In a field survey of twelve facilities handling carbonaceous nanomaterials, Methner et al. (2010) reported that inhalable mass of total carbon concentration (TC) in PBZ samples ranged between 64 and 1094 g/m3, while that from source-specific air samples ranged between 12 and 1839 g/m3. The highest CNF concentration was measured in samples collected during drying and manual scooping of the processed CNF (1839 and 1729 g/m3, respectively). Most of the collected samples showed evidence of CNT/CNF structures by TEM. A task-based comparative assessment by Methner et al. (2012b) found that surface grinding of composite material and manually transferring dry CNF produced substantial increases in particle-number (range = 20,000–490,000 particles/cm3).

In eight-hour work shift PBZ samples (Birch et al., 2011) found respirable EC concentration higher than in the corresponding area air samples. TEM analysis showed that most of the particles collected in the thermal treatment were bundled/entangled structures. Most fibrous particles had aerodynamic diameters <0.25 m. Birch et al. concluded that respirable mass estimated by photometer was the most useful on-site indicator of CNFs while total particle number (9.0 × 104 to 1.15 × 106 per cm3) and active surface area (430–1440 m2/cm3) measurements, determined using direct-reading instruments (DRI), were not useful indicators of CNF exposure. Dahm et al. (2012) visited six primary and secondary manufacturer sites.

Dahm et al. (2012) visited six primary and secondary manufacturer sites. The highest CNT/CNF structure counts from the primary manufacturers came from harvesting operations that did not employ engineering control measures. The two highest structure counts at secondary manufactures were detected during manual transferring of CNF (1.613 and 0.295 structures/cm3). An agreement between the PBZ and area sample collected for the mass concentration of EC and the side-by-side samples collected for TEM analysis was evaluated with a Pearson correlation coefficient of 0.44 (p = 0.01). No clear pattern emerged linking particle number, respirable mass, and active surface-area measurements determined using DRI for EC or TEM data (CNT/CNF-structure counts) (Dahm et al., 2013). The most recent study (Dahm et al., 2015) collected inhalable PBZ samples at nine CNT/CNF manufacturers and users sites and both inhalable and respirable PBZ at five other sites for comparison with the recommended exposure limit (REL) for CNT (1 g/m3 of EC for the respirable size fraction; NIOSH, 2013). Overall, EC PBZ and area samples were below the REL. PBZ samples analyzed by TEM showed concentrations ranging from 0.0001 to 1.613 CNT/CNFstructures/cm3 (geometric mean = 0.008, 8-hour time weighted average (8 h-TWA) = 0.003 structures/cm3). The most common CNT structure sizes were found to be larger agglomerates in the 2–5 m range as well as agglomerates >5 m. A statistically significant correlation was observed between inhalable samples for EC mass and structure counts by TEM (Spearman = 0.39, p < 0.0001). In the Republic of Korea, Han et al. According to Caballero-Guzman et al. (2015), recycling products ontaining CNT/CNF do not result in significant dispersal of nanoaterials to other (new) products. Rather, a large proportion of anomaterials will end-up in waste fractions that will or will not e properly handled. metadata.abstractText: In an emerging field of nanotechnologies, assessment of exposure to carbon nanotubes (CNT) and carbon nanofibers (CNF) is an integral component of occupational and environmental epidemiology, risk assessment and management, as well as regulatory actions. The current state of knowledge on exposure to carbon-based fibrous nanomaterials among workers, consumers and general population was studied in frame of the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) Monographs-Volume 111 “Some Nanomaterials and Some Fibres”. Completeness and reliability of available exposure data for use in epidemiology and risk assessment were assessed. Occupational exposure to CNT/CNF may be of concern at all stages of the material life-cycle from research through manufacture to use and disposal. Consumer and environmental exposures are only estimated by modeled data. The available information of the final xposure metric steps of the life-cycle of these materials remains incomplete so far regarding amounts of handled materials and levels of exposure. The quality and amount of information available on the uses and applications of CNT/CNF should be improved to enable quantitative assessment of human exposure to these materials. For that, coordinated effort in producing surveys and exposure inventories based on harmonized strategy of material test, exposure measurement and reporting results is strongly encouraged. © 2015 Elsevier GmbH. All rights reserved.
